metadata.case_name: Railway Company v. Upper Doab Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Upper Doab Sugar Mills Ltd. manufactures sugar at Shamli and brings sugarcane from nearby stations like Ailum, Kandhla, Khandraoli, Hind, Thanabhawan, Nanautta, Sona Arjunpur via Railway Company's trucks.

Mills has a siding agreement with Railway Company; trucks brought by Railway locomotives to point A (100-150 ft from Shamli station platform), then Mills arranges further movement inside sidings for unloading.

Prior to October 1, 1953, charges for sugarcane: From Ailum, Kandhla, Khandraoli, Hind, Thanabhawan: Rs. 3-8-0 plus surcharge; Nanautta, Sona Arjunpur: Rs. 4-4-0 plus surcharge. No terminal charges levied.
Central Government order dated February 20, 1950 under s.32 Indian Railways Act fixed terminal charges: 6 pies per maund at each end where owners do loading/unloading.

Railway Company issued Local Rate Advice on August 1, 1953 effective October 1, 1953: station-to-station rates plus terminal Rs.9.6 per 4-wheeler, increasing total charges e.g. Ailum from Rs.3-8 to Rs.11-12.
Mills filed complaint No.2 of 1954 under s.41(1)(i) Indian Railways Act to Railway Rates Tribunal against increase; other prayers withdrawn.
Railway Rates Tribunal majority (Shri L.M. Roy, Shri V. Subrahmanyan) held not standardized terminals, services only at loading end, reduced terminal to Rs.4.11 annas.
Tribunal President Mr. Lokur (minority) held no jurisdiction as standardized terminals, services at both ends.
Siding agreement Clause 13: Freight charged up to/from Shamli station; additional charges for placing/removing wagons from lines A/B; engine use Rs.5 per transaction.
Siding agreement Clause 15(a): Wagons handled by Railway to/from lines A/B; considered made over at line A.
Average load per 4-wheeler truck: 200 mds. (capacity basis); carriage charged per truck on 150 mds. basis.
Rs.9.6 terminal = 6 pies per maund on 150 mds. at each end.

legal_issues.text: When total charges payable in respect of goods traffic carried by a Railway are increased by the Railway Administration on the basis of terminals fixed by the Central Government in pursuance of s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act, has the Railway Rates Tribunal jurisdiction to investigate the reasonableness of the charge as thus increased?
Whether Rs.9.6 is application of standardized terminal charges fixed under s.32, or a distinct charge.
Interpretation of 'terminals' in s.3(14): charges for provision/maintenance or only for use/services rendered thereat.
Where carriage ends and terminal services begin, per siding agreement and facts.

petitioner_arguments.text: Increasing charges merely applied standardized terminal charges notified by Central Government under s.32; no complaint lies under s.41(1)(i).
Considerable services rendered by Railway at both ends apart from carriage, justifying terminals.

respondent_arguments.text: Rs.9.6 fixed as lump sum per 4-wheeler irrespective of maundage, not application of 6 pies per maund standardized rate.
Services rendered only at loading station, not at Shamli end (conveyance ends at point A).

court_reasoning.text: Rs.9.6 equivalent to 6 pies/maund on 150 mds. at each end; parties agree on capacity basis without actual weighment; thus application of Govt. fixed rate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fixation of lump sum on agreed weight basis deemed application of standardized charge.

court_reasoning.text: Local Rate Advice inaccuracy in expression (station-to-station rate plus terminal) does not affect substance; terminals distinct from rates per s.3(13), s.46C(g).
Per siding Cl.13, freight to Shamli station platform; haulage to point A additional service (terminal), not carriage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Carriage charged to platform; beyond is terminal service.

court_reasoning.text: 'Terminals' s.3(14) includes charges for provision/maintenance of stations/sidings etc., irrespective of use or additional services; wide 'in respect of'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Leviable for mere provision, not just user/services.

court_reasoning.text: s.41 excludes standardized terminals from complaints; Tribunal no jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Railway Rates Tribunal has no jurisdiction under s.41 to investigate reasonableness of standardized terminal charges fixed under s.32.
Rs.9.6 per 4-wheeler is application of standardized terminals (6 pies/maund on 150 mds. basis).
'Terminals' under s.3(14) leviable for provision of stations/sidings etc., irrespective of actual use.
Haulage from Shamli platform to point A is terminal service, not carriage.

precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between conveyance and terminal services; haulage beyond certain point prima facie terminal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hall & Co. v. London, Brighton and South Coast Rly. Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Provision of station accommodation and sidings entitles to terminal charges as incidental to carrier duty.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railways Act, 1890
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixing standardized terminals; jurisdiction of Tribunal; definitions of rate, terminals, station-to-station rate.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside majority order of Railway Rates Tribunal dated April 20, 1955; held Tribunal lacked jurisdiction as charges were standardized terminals under s.32; rejected Mills' complaint under s.41.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; Tribunal order set aside; complaint rejected.

key_quotes.text: "When total charges payable in respect of goods traffic carried by a Railway are increased by the Railway Administration on the basis of terminals fixed by the Central Government in pursuance of s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act, has the Railway Rates Tribunal jurisdiction to investigate the reasonableness of the charge as thus increased?"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The words 'in respect of' used in s. 3(14) means for the provision of and not for the user of."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key interpretation allowing terminals irrespective of use.

key_quotes.text: "Freight for all classes of goods will be charged up to and from Shamli station."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From siding agreement Cl.13; determines end of carriage.
